column5: "a quick question" (#http://groups.yahoo.com/group/mythsoc/message/24071 24071 and related messages; dated 29 January 2013)
column6: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/mythsoc/ Mytsoc mailing list (accessed 30 January 2012) was the original name of the High-Elven tongue which gradually would change into Quenya of the The Lord of the Rings.

column1: In the earliest versions of the legendarium
column2: Qenya (as every Elvish language) belonged to the Oromëan phylum
column3: derived from the language Oromë taught the Quendi. It was the language of the First Tribe of the Elves
column4: the Lindar (Vanyar in the later legendarium) and for this it was also called Lindarin. In Gnomish the name of the language was Cweneglin or Cwedhrin.

column1: Qenya goes back to at least 1915 when Tolkien compiled the "Qenya Lexicon". Qenya thus predates the Legendarium
column2: although the Lexicon was used in parallel to The Book of Lost Tales a couple of years later. According to Tolkien
column3: his secondary world was created primarily for the need to make his constructed languages usable.

column1: Qenya was started by Tolkien who wished to emulate the phonoesthetics of the Finnish language. Early Qenya has been reported to have much more Finnish influences

column2: Tolkien used to write the sound  simply as a single q. Therefore both spellings Qenya and Quenya are always supposed to be pronounced the same (). While writing the Lord of the Rings
column3: Tolkien decided to adopt the romanized spelling qu and replace k with c. These changes were mainly aesthetic in order to accentuate the role of Quenya as an "Elf-latin". This does not alter the pronunciation.

column2: the early stage of Qenya displayed some differences
column3: with words such as ektar (kt is not allowed in later Quenya) and words ending in consonant clusters
column7: koisimatl etc. The later phonology rules of Quenya would not allow such words.

column1: Since the High-Elven language changed throughout Tolkiens lifetime from its conception until late in his life
column2: some Tolkienists and linguists deliberately use the spelling "Qenya" (without "u") to differentiate the early version of this language from the later.

column1: Such Tolkien linguists note "a dramatic change" after which the language somehow stabilized after 1940. One of such changes was that later Quenya does not display the "number of borrowings and obvious influences of real-world languages" that Qenya did.
Helge Fauskanger used to refer to the early stage(s) of Quenya as "immature Qenya".The term "early Q(u)enya" was also used
column2: but it was ambiguous as the words "early" and "later" are also used in respect to the fictional timeline of Arda. The above phrase would be understood either as the early version of the language (from Tolkiens youth)
column3: or an archaic form of Valinorean Quenya of the First Age (vs. the later
column4: Exilic Quenya of the Third Age). To resolve the ambiguity
column6: from the point of view of Tolkiens lifetime (from youth to maturity).

column1: The differentiation between Qenya and Quenya has been criticized as artificial
column2: since it neglects the continuity and gradual evolution of the language; although Tolkien replaced old ideas with newer ones
column3: there is no indication that he divided his conception into stages
column4: and no definite point which separates Qenya from Quenya can be traced. Also
column5: the term "immature" was considered controversial and derogatory.Patrick Wynne

column2: http://www.phy.duke.edu/~trenk/elvish/eqg.html Early Qenya grammar (includes comparisons with later Quenya elements)
